questions.question: Is there an enterprise cybersecurity program that aligns objectives with business strategy and risk?
questions.evidence: Review program charter, risk assessments, and executive reports.

options.text: Not performed or ad hoc. Limited visibility. No ownership.
Initial and compliance-driven. Some centralization or basic practice. Inconsistent.
Documented and resourced. Targeted coverage and defined workflow. Basic metrics.
Policy-guided and accountable. Holistic coverage. Effectiveness tracked. Skilled staff.
Optimized and proactive. 24/7 operations. Extensive automation. Continuous improvement.

questions.question: Do you run a SOC metrics program with clear objectives, data sources, synthesis, and decisioning?
questions.evidence: Review KPI/KRI dashboards and records of metric-driven decisions.

options.text: Not performed or ad hoc.
Basic, inconsistent metrics (e.g., ticket volume).
Defined operational metrics (MTTD, MTTR) are tracked.
Metrics are tied to risk and influence priorities.
Metrics program is predictive and drives automated actions.

questions.question: Do you set target maturity levels per domain and track progress against them?
questions.evidence: Review maturity assessment reports and strategic roadmaps.

options.text: No targets are set.
Informal goals exist but are not tracked.
Target maturity levels are documented for some domains.
Targets are set for all domains and progress is reviewed quarterly.
Targets are continuously adjusted based on threat landscape and business risk.

Risk & Threat Intelligence.subtitle: Integrating risk context and threat intelligence.

questions.question: Is risk management used to prioritize SOC use cases and investments?
questions.evidence: Show mapping of detection use cases to enterprise risk register.

options.text: Not performed or ad hoc.
Risk is considered informally.
Use cases are loosely mapped to general risks.
A formal process aligns SOC priorities with the enterprise risk register.
Risk models dynamically adjust detection and response priorities.

questions.question: Is threat intelligence integrated into detections and investigations?
questions.evidence: Demonstrate automated TI enrichment in alerts and hunting queries.

options.text: No TI is used.
Analysts manually consult public TI feeds.
TI feeds are ingested, but integration is manual or limited.
TI is automatically correlated with logs and enriches alerts.
Proactive threat hunting is driven by tailored, predictive intelligence.

questions.question: Are third-party risks monitored and incidents coordinated with suppliers?
questions.evidence: Review third-party incident response plans and communication records.

options.text: No monitoring of third-party risk.
Informal awareness of supplier incidents.
Third-party security is assessed, but not actively monitored.
There is a formal program for third-party IR coordination.
Automated monitoring of the external attack surface of key suppliers.

questions.question: What is your centralized logging coverage across endpoint, server, network, identity, SaaS, and cloud?
questions.evidence: Show logging coverage dashboard and data source inventory.

options.text: No centralized logging.
Only critical infrastructure logs are centralized.
Majority of security-relevant logs are centralized with basic retention.
Comprehensive logging coverage across all key asset types.
Coverage is continuously validated and gaps are automatically flagged.

questions.question: What endpoint and network detection coverage and configuration is in place?
questions.evidence: Review EDR/NDR deployment stats and configuration policies.

options.text: No EDR/NDR tools.
Deployed on some critical assets, default configuration.
Widely deployed with some policy tuning.
Fully deployed with tailored policies and regular health checks.
Integrated EDR/NDR telemetry drives automated response actions.

questions.question: Do you monitor and normalize telemetry quality with schema and parsing guards?
questions.evidence: Show data quality dashboards and examples of parsing rules.

options.text: No data quality monitoring.
Ad-hoc fixes for parsing errors.
A process exists to handle common parsing issues.
Data is normalized to a common schema; quality is monitored.
Automated data quality validation with self-healing capabilities.

questions.question: Do you maintain a versioned detection catalog mapped to ATT&CK and risks?
questions.evidence: Show the detection catalog in a repository or management tool.

options.text: No catalog exists.
Informal list of detections.
A catalog exists, but is not consistently maintained or mapped.
Version-controlled catalog mapped to ATT&CK is actively used.
Catalog is integrated with automated testing and coverage analysis.

questions.question: Are detections tested, tuned, and retired through a managed lifecycle?
questions.evidence: Show change logs and testing procedures for detection rules.

options.text: No defined lifecycle.
Detections are created but rarely tuned or retired.
A manual process for tuning and review exists.
A formal CI/CD-like lifecycle for detection content is implemented.
Lifecycle is fully automated, including simulated attack testing.

questions.question: Is alert fidelity measured and improved via precision/recall or SNR?
questions.evidence: Review alert fidelity metrics and reports showing tuning effectiveness.

options.text: Fidelity is not measured.
Analysts provide informal feedback on noisy alerts.
Alerts are manually tagged as false positives; basic stats are kept.
Formal Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) is tracked per detection.
Automated feedback loops adjust alert scores based on analyst actions.

questions.question: Is there a hypothesis-led hunting program with scheduled cadence?
questions.evidence: Show hunt calendar, hypothesis backlog, and post-hunt reports.

options.text: No threat hunting.
Ad-hoc, unstructured hunting occurs occasionally.
Scheduled hunts occur, but may lack formal hypotheses.
A formal program with hypothesis-driven hunts is established.
Hunting is continuous and integrated with intelligence.

questions.question: Do hunters have access to rich historical data and flexible query tools?
questions.evidence: Demonstrate hunting platform and access to diverse datasets.

options.text: No dedicated tools or data access.
Hunters use SIEM, but access is limited.
Hunters have access to most relevant data, but tools are not specialized.
Dedicated hunting platform with broad data access and long retention.
Hunters have programmatic access to all data and can build custom tools.

questions.question: Are hunt findings converted into detections and playbooks?
questions.evidence: Trace a hunt finding to a new detection rule and updated playbook.

options.text: Findings are not formally documented or used.
Findings are noted, but not systematically converted.
A manual process exists to create detections from hunt findings.
A formal, tracked process ensures findings become new detections.
The process is semi-automated, with templates for new detections.

questions.question: Do analysts use a case platform with evidence, linkage, and audit trail?
questions.evidence: Show an example case with linked artifacts and analyst notes.

options.text: No case management platform.
Shared spreadsheets or documents are used.
A ticketing system is used, but not tailored for security cases.
A dedicated case management platform is used consistently.
Case platform is integrated with all tools for full audit trail.

questions.question: Is triage enriched automatically and consistently?
questions.evidence: Show an alert automatically enriched with user, asset, and TI data.

options.text: No enrichment.
Analysts manually gather context for alerts.
Basic, inconsistent automated enrichment.
Consistent, automated enrichment for all alerts.
Dynamic enrichment that adapts based on the alert type.

questions.question: Is there shared knowledge, runbooks, and cross-team collaboration?
questions.evidence: Show wiki/knowledge base, runbooks, and collaboration channels.

options.text: No shared knowledge or collaboration.
Informal collaboration (e.g., chat).
Some runbooks and a basic knowledge base exist.
A comprehensive, actively maintained knowledge base and runbooks are used.
Knowledge is captured automatically from investigations.

questions.question: Are IR plans/playbooks documented, tested, and exercised?
questions.evidence: Show IR playbooks and reports from recent tabletop or live-fire exercises.

options.text: No documented playbooks.
Basic playbooks exist but are not tested.
Playbooks are documented and occasionally tested via tabletops.
Playbooks are regularly tested and updated after live-fire exercises.
Playbooks are executable (SOAR) and tested automatically.

questions.question: Do you provide 24/7 coverage with defined roles and escalation?
questions.evidence: Show on-call schedule, escalation matrix, and role definitions.

options.text: No 24/7 coverage or formal on-call.
Best-effort on-call, no formal escalation.
Formal on-call rotation with basic escalation path.
24/7 coverage with well-defined roles and multi-tiered escalation.
Follow-the-sun model with fully staffed shifts.

questions.question: Are PIRs conducted and improvements tracked to closure?
questions.evidence: Show a Post-Incident Report (PIR) and the associated tracking ticket.

options.text: No PIR process.
Informal lessons learned are sometimes discussed.
A formal PIR process exists but follow-up is inconsistent.
PIRs are consistently conducted and action items are tracked to closure.
PIR findings feed directly into risk management and automated control testing.

questions.question: Is triage automated for common alerts with guardrails?
questions.evidence: Show a SOAR playbook that automates triage for phishing alerts.

options.text: No automation.
Basic scripts exist for simple tasks.
Some triage tasks are automated for high-volume, low-risk alerts.
A SOAR platform is used to automate triage for multiple alert types.
Most triage is automated, with analysts handling only exceptions.

questions.question: Are data gathering and enrichment automated during investigations?
questions.evidence: Show a playbook that gathers context from multiple tools for an investigation.

options.text: No automation.
Analysts use scripts to query some tools.
Some data gathering is automated within the SIEM/case tool.
SOAR automates data gathering from multiple sources (e.g., EDR, logs, TI).
Automated investigation proposes root cause and next steps.

questions.question: Is mitigation automated for low-risk patterns and semi-automated for higher risk?
questions.evidence: Show a playbook that blocks an IP or isolates a host.

options.text: No automated response.
Scripts exist but require manual execution.
Fully automated response for very specific, low-impact events.
Semi-automated response (human-in-the-loop) for critical actions.
Fully automated response for a wide range of threats with strong guardrails.

questions.question: Do you have adequate staffing and a role-based skills matrix?
questions.evidence: Show staffing plan, org chart, and skills matrix.

options.text: No formal staffing plan or skills tracking.
Staffing is reactive; skills are not formally defined.
A staffing plan and basic role definitions exist.
A skills matrix is used to guide hiring and training.
Skills matrix is linked to career progression and automated training.

questions.question: Is there a formal training program and budget for SOC roles?
questions.evidence: Show training budget, plan, and records of completed training.

options.text: No training budget or program.
Training is ad-hoc and self-directed.
A training budget exists, but no formal program.
A formal, role-based training program is in place.
Training effectiveness is measured and tied to performance.

questions.question: Do you run regular tabletop and live-fire exercises?
questions.evidence: Show schedule and reports from recent exercises.

options.text: No exercises are performed.
Occasional, informal tabletops.
Scheduled tabletop exercises are conducted annually.
Regular tabletop and live-fire exercises for the whole team.
Exercises are based on specific threat intelligence and results are tracked.

questions.question: Is detection and response aligned with segmentation and zero-trust design?
questions.evidence: Show detection rules that leverage network segments or identity context.

options.text: Flat network, no zero-trust principles applied.
Some network segmentation exists but is not used by SOC.
Alerts are manually correlated with network location.
Detection logic and asset criticality are based on network segments.
Zero-trust signals (e.g., device health) are integral to detection and response.

questions.question: Are crown jewels identified and instrumented with priority detections?
questions.evidence: Show inventory of critical assets and associated high-priority detections.

options.text: No asset criticality defined.
Informal understanding of critical assets.
Critical assets are tagged, but monitoring is not differentiated.
Critical assets have heightened monitoring and faster response SLAs.
Asset criticality dynamically adjusts monitoring and response automation.

questions.question: Can you withstand outages with resilient, tamper-evident logging?
questions.evidence: Show architecture for log pipeline redundancy and immutability.

options.text: Single point of failure in logging pipeline.
Some redundancy, but no tamper-evidence.
Logging pipeline is redundant.
Logs are stored in immutable, tamper-evident storage.
Automated failover and integrity checks for the entire logging pipeline.
